body.p: Four students attempt to register online at the same time for an Introductory Statistics class that is full. Two are freshmen and two are sophomores. They are put on a wait list. Prior to the start of the semester, two enrolled students drop the course, so the professor decides to randomly select two of the four wait list students and gives them a seat in the class.
What is the probability that both students selected are freshmen?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have been thinking that half of the wait list students are freshmen. But you need to think about the sample space of this random experiment. Since order does not matter, the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes. S = {F1F2, F1S1, F1S2, F2S1, F2S2, S1S2}.

Incorrect. You may have been thinking that there are four possible outcomes, {FF, FS, SF, and SS}, like when we toss a coin two times. But here the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes because there are 2 freshmen and 2 sophomores and the order in which they are chosen does not matter. S = {F1F2, F1S1, F1S2, F2S1, F2S2, S1S2}.

Correct. The order that the students are chosen does not matter, so F1F2 and F2F1 are the same outcome. Thus, the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes. S = {F1F2, F1S1, F1S2, F2S1, F2S2, S1S2}.

Incorrect. The order that the students are chosen does not matter, so F1F2 and F2F1 are the same outcome. Thus, the sample space contains only six equally likely outcomes. S = {F1F2, F1S1, F1S2, F2S1, F2S2, S1S2}.

body.p: In the last round of a chess tournament the final match is between Alice and Diego. The winner is the first player to win three games [sometimes called “best of 5”]. Assume that they are equally matched, so that each player has an equal probability of winning each game. What is the probability that the match will be finished after the first 3 games are played?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the probability that Alice or Diego will win a game. Consider the results of the first three games that are played. You will find that there are 8 equally likely outcomes in this sample space. Note that the only way for the match to be finished in these first three games is if Alice wins all three games (AAA) or Diego wins all three games (DDD).

Correct. Considering the results of the first three games that are played, we find that there are 8 equally likely outcomes in this sample space (AAA, AAD, ADA, ADD, DDD, DDA, DAD, DAA). The only way for the match to be resolved in these first three games is if Alice wins all three games (AAA) or Diego wins all three games (DDD), so the probability is 2/8 = 0.25.

Incorrect. You may have focused on the fact that they might play 5 games. For this problem, we only need to consider the results of the first three games that are played. You will find that there are 8 equally likely outcomes in this sample space. Note that the only way for the match to be finished in these first three games is if Alice wins all three games (AAA) or Diego wins all three games (DDD).

Incorrect. You correctly identified that there are 8 outcomes in the sample space, but this is the probability of one correct outcome. Note that there are two ways that the match can be resolved in 3 games: Either Alice wins all three games (AAA) or Diego wins all three games (DDD).

body.p: For a criminal trial, 8 active and 4 alternate jurors are selected. Two of the alternate jurors are male and two are female. During the trial, two of the active jurors are dismissed. The judge decides to randomly select two replacement jurors from the 4 available alternates. What is the probability that both jurors selected are female?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have been thinking that half of the jurors are female. But you need to think about the sample space of this random experiment. Since order does not matter, the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes. S = {F1F2, F1M1, F1M2, F2M1, F2M2, M1M2}.

Incorrect. You may have been thinking that there are four possible outcomes, {FF, FM, MF, and MM}, like when we toss a coin two times. But here the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes because there are 2 female and 2 males and the order in which they are chosen does not matter, S = {F1F2, F1M1, F1M2, F2M1, F2M2, M1M2}.

Correct. The order that the jurors are chosen does not matter, so F1F2 and F2F1 are the same outcome. Thus, the sample space contains six equally likely outcomes. S = {F1F2, F1M1, F1M2, F2M1, F2M2, M1M2}. Only one of the six outcomes is two females.

body.p: A True/False quiz has three questions. When guessing, the probability of getting a question correct is the same as the probability of getting a question wrong. What is the probability that a student that guesses gets at least 2 questions correct? (Give your answer to 2 decimal places)

response.feedback: Correct. There are 8 equally likely outcomes in this sample space. Four of the outcomes (CCW, CWC, WCC, CCC) have at least 2 questions correct. So the probability is 4/8 = 0.5 that at least 2 questions are guessed correctly.
